image.altText: Head shot of MasterChef Jock Zonfrillo, who is standing in front of a large pile of chefs' aprons.

items.synopsis: Born in Glasgow, Zonfrillo operated renowned restaurants in Sydney and Adelaide over two decades before becoming a judge on MasterChef in 2019.

title.children: Jock Zonfrillo, celebrated chef and judge on MasterChef Australia, dies aged 46

image.altText: Jock takes a selfie with the other judges.

items.synopsis: The MasterChef community has been rocked by the sudden death of judge Jock Zonfrillo, who is being remembered for his “charisma, wicked sense of humour, generosity and passion”.

title.children: MasterChef judge Jock Zonfrillo remembered for 'wicked sense of humour' — as it happened

image.altText: A hand holding a phone with Snapchat open.

items.synopsis: Connor Manns is accused of firing three shots at another man with the intent to kill him in 2021, when the two agreed to meet at Casey shops after a Snapchat dispute.

title.children: Man on trial for alleged attempted murder at Canberra shops dubbed 'duplicitous' by own lawyer

image.altText: A small scaly earless dragon sits on a rock.

items.synopsis: The ACT government has updated its list of threatened species and says the Canberra grassland earless dragon is now critically endangered. Five new species have been added to the list, while four have had their status updated.

title.children: Canberra grassland earless dragon headed for extinction as ACT government criticises airport development plan

image.altText: a young woman walking outdoors after leaving a court house

items.synopsis: The daughter of a former deputy commissioner at the Australian Tax Office is sentenced to a maximum of eight years in prison for her role in a $105 million tax fraud conspiracy.

title.children: Lauren Cranston jailed for eight years over one of Australia's biggest tax frauds

image.altText: A man raises a hand while performing a dance move.

items.synopsis: Ian Smith, the husband of former Democrats leader Natasha Stott Despoja, busted out the move in front of an audience including Julie Bishop, Malcolm Turnbull and Hollywood A-listers Kate Beckinsale, Sienna Miller and Kate Moss at a gala dinner in New York last week.

title.children: 'The worm goes global': Rita Ora wowed by Adelaide lobbyist's dancefloor moves

image.altText: Abbott gestures with a grin as he sits on a committee bench inside parliament.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Tony Abbott has offered a staunch criticism of a proposed constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament, just hours after getting into a spat with a parliamentary committee investigating the looming referendum.

title.children: Tony Abbott mounts attack on Voice after a spat with parliamentary committee

image.altText: A group of four people standing in front of saluting paramedics, clearly overwhelmed with emotion.

items.synopsis: Steven Tougher's expecting wife was among those who paid tribute to the 29-year-old at an emotional service in Wollongong.

title.children: 'They will forever know their dad was a hero': 1,000 mourners farewell slain NSW paramedic

image.altText: Glass on ground with Maryborough town sign in background

items.synopsis: One of the victims of a horror triple-fatal crash in Maryborough, allegedly involving a stolen vehicle, was a nurse who had just finished her shift at the local hospital. Her colleagues were among the first responders.

title.children: Nurse driving home from shift among victims of triple-fatal crash involving allegedly stolen car

image.altText: A composite image of Marion Scrymgour, Lidia Thorpe and Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

items.synopsis: The 2022 federal election delivered record results for First Nations representation in parliament. Ahead of the referendum, the ABC contacted the 11 politicians to hear directly from them what they think about a constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament.

title.children: There are 11 First Nations MPs and senators. Here's what they think of a Voice to Parliament

image.altText: a man with blood coming from his mouth after being hit

items.synopsis: The man accused of punching and kicking a soccer referee in the head after a Friday night match in Sydney is refused bail.

title.children: Soccer spectator accused of punching out teeth of referee in 'outrageous attack' refused bail

image.altText: A submarine moves through the water towards the camera, in the day time. The shoreline can be seen in the distance.

items.synopsis: Until Australia's submarine fleet can go nuclear the navy must keep its near-retirement vessels deployable. It's been a struggle.

title.children: How Australia was left with only one deployable submarine

image.altText: a man and a car with bullet holes

items.synopsis: Morning raids lead to the arrest of two men as investigations into the alleged underworld hit continue.

title.children: Police investigating gangland shooting allegedly uncover separate murder plot

image.altText: A sepia-tone image of Broderick Smith as a young man, with 70s shoulder-length hair and a steady gaze.

items.synopsis: Broderick Smith dies peacefully at home, aged 75, after a career playing blues, boogie, country and rock across Australia and the world.

title.children: Musician Broderick Smith dies peacefully at home, aged 75, after career spanning decades

image.altText: debris can be seen on the ground in a residential area after a military strike

items.synopsis: Ukrainian air defence crews destroy missiles launched by Russian forces in the early hours of Monday morning, the military said, as air raid sirens blared across the country for more than three hours.

title.children: Ukrainian air defences shoot down 15 of 18 Russian missiles launched in dead of night

image.altText: A man points and yells during a rugby league match

items.synopsis: After a grand final finished 1-0 over the weekend, take a walk down memory lane with some of the lowest scoring matches in Australian rugby league history.

title.children: A short history of the lowest-scoring matches in rugby league history

image.altText: Steven Hocking and Gillon McLachlan sit in front of Andrew Dillon at an AFL ground.

items.synopsis: The AFL has named Andrew Dillon its next chief executive, taking over from Gillon McLachlan, who announced his upcoming resignation almost a year ago.

title.children: 'I don't buy that one bit': Next AFL CEO denies claims of a boys' club after promotion from general counsel

image.altText: Four women stand next to each other wearing red and white football jumpers.

items.synopsis: South Bunbury Australian rules football player Kelly Bevis has made club history after playing her first league game on a team alongside her three daughters.

title.children: Football's a family affair for these WA sisters, who play alongside their mum

image.altText: Heather Mitchell stands with two drinks in her hand in a room lit by a table lamp

items.synopsis: Actor Heather Mitchell's life has been as dramatic off screen as it has on. And she’s channelling those experiences into some of the greatest performances of her career.

title.children: How Heather Mitchell survived a 'testosterone, cocaine and alcohol-fuelled' workplace

image.altText: A worker smooths concrete at slab pour at building construction site at Radar Street at Lytton at Brisbane.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of infrastructure projects promised by the former federal government are not properly funded and may be cancelled if a major review deems they cannot be delivered.

title.children: Hundreds of 'completely underfunded' Coalition-era infrastructure projects on the chopping block

image.altText: King Charles walks past a line of men holding their swords upwards. He is wearing a royal uniform.

items.synopsis: The Archbishop of Canterbury has asked members of the public to pledge their allegiance to King Charles III during his coronation on Saturday. Here's what that will look like.

title.children: The public will be asked to pledge allegiance to King Charles III. This is what you need to know

image.altText: A large elephant sits in the back of a truck with its trunk resting on a wooden fence in the truck.

items.synopsis: The male elephant known as Arikomban, or "rice-tusker" -- was infamous for raiding shops for rice and grains in the southern state of Kerala.

title.children: Rice-loving Asian elephant captured and relocated after killing six people in India

image.altText: Karl Lagerfeld standing in front of a technological backdrop, wearing a black suit, dark sunglasses and fingerless gloves

items.synopsis: This year's Met Gala is all about the late fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld. Given his past comments about women's bodies, the #MeToo movement and the Syrian refugee crisis, the theme has not been without critics.

title.children: Why is the Karl Lagerfeld theme for the Met Gala so controversial?

image.altText: Man wearing sunnies and baseball cap holding a fish.

items.synopsis: Kevin Darmody — described by friends as a friendly bloke who loved a "good yarn" — was fishing by the Kennedy River north-west of Cairns when he disappeared from the bank where he was fishing.

title.children: Search continues for well-known publican feared taken by croc in Queensland's far north

image.altText: A grey crocodile with a pointed beak inside a bright purple plastic bin.

items.synopsis: A metre-long female crocodile, believed to be an escaped or dumped pet, was found jammed against a fence by Umina home owners while doing some yard work on Sunday.

title.children: 'Thought it was a toy:' Metre-long croc found in backyard of NSW Central Coast home

image.altText: An African lady smiling in her new social housing residence

items.synopsis: The Parliamentary Budget Office warns phasing out property tax breaks may "trigger a significant economic shock". That's why next week's budget is more focused on increasing the supply of housing rather than trying to make housing affordable by reducing house prices.

title.children: Phasing out property tax breaks could save $74b but it also could create 'significant economic shock'

image.altText: A soccer player wearing blue lifts a trophy as blue and white confetti flies through the air

items.synopsis: Three years ago, Sydney FC's players were "nobodies." Now, as the A-League Women's most successful club, they have become their own legacy.

title.children: Sydney FC's fourth A-League Women championship fulfils their own living legacy

image.altText: An animation of Earth being orbited by hundreds of objects.

items.synopsis: For millennia humans have gazed up at the wonder of the night sky, but what we can see is rapidly changing because of our quest to be connected.

title.children: Earth's orbit is becoming more crowded and our window to the universe is at stake

image.altText: A woman's hands resting in her lap. She's wearing rings, bracelets and a watch

items.synopsis: Prisha's elderly neighbour had heard the commotion coming from her Brisbane home for months and decided to take action. The small act of kindness changed the migrant's life.

title.children: Prisha didn't realise she was suffering from domestic violence. To her, it was 'normal'

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: Australia's share market gained last week and awaits a key rates decision on Tuesday. Follow the day's events with our blog.

title.children: ASX set to rise after positive week

schema.headline: Live updates: ASX starts again after lifting last week, global stock markets move

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Local market posts a positive start to the week
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: There we have it — the local share market has managed to hold on to a gain and finish around a third of a per cent higher on Monday. That's despite losing steam through the afternoon— here's a chart of how the All Ordinaries tracked over the session: Meanwhile, the ASX 200 rose 0.35 per cent to 7,334.6 points, with big banks and energy stocks doing some of the heavy lifting. Mining stocks were a drag on the market, limiting the gains, with BHP and South 32 in the red, alongside gold and lithium miners. And Fortescue and Rio Tinto shares ended virtually unchanged. Here's how the different sectors fared on the benchmark index: And the biggest individual stock moves: Tomorrow is set to be an interesting day, with the Reserve Bank rates decision at 2:30pm AEST. Market pricing suggests no change to the cash rate for a second month in a row but some economists, including those at the Commonwealth Bank, are betting on a final 0.25% hike. My colleague Kate Ainsworth will be on deck early with all the overseas market action. Have a good afternoon!

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX on track to close higher
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good afternoon — Steph Chalmers here jumping on to take you through the closing numbers in just a few minutes time. After posting two straight weekly losses, it's a fairly positive start to this week, with the ASX 200 and All Ords looking on track to finish higher. The banks are doing some heavy lifting while the major miners are mixed. I'll have the final figures for you very shortly.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: House prices back to rising
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you were part of the group that hoped falling house prices would allow them to get into a hot market just beyond their reach... I have more bad news. My colleague Kate Ainsworth has analysed CoreLogic data and the median value of homes sold across the country increased by 0.5 per cent in April, following a 0.6 per cent increase in March. Given interest rates are paused and inflation has started to fall (at least in data, even if it doesn't feel like it) this is potentially the end of any slump in house prices based on rocketing rates. CoreLogic's research director, Tim Lawless, said that, despite the divergence, the figures suggested Australia's housing market downturn had passed. "Not only are we seeing housing values stabilising or rising across most areas of the country, a number of other indicators are confirming the positive shift," he said. "Auction clearance rates are holding slightly above the long-run average, sentiment has lifted and home sales are trending around the previous five-year average."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Rents climb $130 a week in just three years
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The housing crunch in Australia has been a growing concern for years. The figures keep getting worse. As my colleague Nassim Khadem notes in this report... The focus on housing affordability, politically, comes amid a new report from PowerHousing Australia, based on CoreLogic data, suggesting national median rents climbed from $440 per week in January 2020 to $570 per week in March 2023 — an increase of $130 a week or $6,760 a year. And, with the Reserve Bank of Australia lifting its benchmark interest rate from 0.1 per cent in May last year to 3.6 per cent over 10 consecutive moves — and some economists predicting another 0.25 per cent rise will be delivered on Tuesday — more Australians could fall into housing stress.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Mortgage majors dominate
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Australia has a highly concentrated banking sector, meaning there are a few massive players, a couple or smaller ones and a score of tiny ones. They 'compete' but the heft of the largest ones - in market power, pricing power, marketing power and more - makes it pretty tough for their competitors. New data from the prudential regulator APRA shows just how substantial that heft is. The 'Big Four' - ANZ, Commonwealth Bank (CBA) NAB and Westpac (WBC)' - are unable to merge with or takeover each other. Check out their share of the mortgage market, they're the four on the left. Together it's 75.1% - more than three-quarters of all home loans in the nation. Fighting over the rest are Bendigo and Adelaide Bank (BEN) Bank of Queensland (BOQ) Macquarie (MQC) and others.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Why is the market up today?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Question for you: Why is the stock market up today? I know the markets in the US were up on Friday but this is the day before the RBA meeting and for the past few months investors have been really cautious the day before the RBA meeting.  Is this a sign that they think rates will remain the same? Is this uptick because of the US markets?  Or is there some secret alchemy at work, like Mars is transversing Venus while the sea urchins mate in Turkey?  - Trying to find rhyme or reason. The ASX 200 is up 0.5% in morning trade, lifting 41 points to be 7,350.20 points. The broader All Ordinaries Index of the biggest 500 companies is up 0.5% too, rising 40.5 points to be 7,541.50 points But why? This is a good question. Our commentator makes some solids suggestions as to why. The real answer is: no-one knows. The market is composed of millions of transactions where people transfer the ownership of stocks. There aren't really 'more buyers than sellers' as you sometimes hear - one must meet the other to make the trade, so the number is the same. All of this leans towards the Mars/Venus/Turkish sea urchins theory being the best answer.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Stock market morning movers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Almost everything heading up in the first morning of stock market trading for the week. Healthcare stocks the leader, up 2%, followed by energy. They've been driven by Resmed, up 6.2% or 28 cents to $8.50 and lithium miner Lake Resources, up 7.1% or 3 cents to 45 cents. Other big movers include Whitehaven Coal (3.5%) Pinnacle Investment Management (3.3%) and News Corporation (2.7%).

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Federal Budget in a week
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Look, the most important day is always today. But with the RBA meeting tomorrow and the Federal Budget next week, let's look ahead a bit. The biggest bank in the nation, the Commonwealth Bank, has put out its preview of next Tuesday's budget and it spells out some assumptions that will help you frame the size of the challenge facing the nation. Here's what the bank says the government is trying to do, at the same time: maintaining fiscal discipline to assist monetary policy in bringing inflation back to the 2%-3% target range providing some targeted relief to cost-of-living pressures putting in place new arrangements to reverse the projected blowout in spending on a number of large programs (ie. NDIS, Aged care) implementing the AUKUS defence policy priorities further developing climate change policies implementing some tax reform and moving the medium-term budget outlook onto a more sustainable footing And don't forget — win the next election so you can start working on the really hard stuff! That said, there's some good news for Treasurer Jim Chalmers. There was a budget last year — in October 2022 — to enact a lot of election promises. The 2022/23 budget deficit is expected to come in well below the estimate that was made then. Data to March shows the 2022/23 deficit running at $A11.2 billion "a substantial $A23.3 billion lower than expectations". If you roll it over 12 months like in this chart, the budget is back to a (very) small surplus — mainly thanks to the strong labour market and company profits.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX 200 opens up 0.65%
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The index of Australia's 200 biggest listed companies has opened up in the first day of trading for the week. The ASX 200 is up 0.62% or 45.3 points to 7,354.30 points.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's where we're sitting at 8:30am AEDT
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX SPI 200 futures: +0.7% to 7,372 Aussie dollar: 66.09 US cents On Wall Street: Dow +0.8%, S & P 500 =).8%, NASDAQ 0.7% In Europe: FTSE 100 +0.5%, Stoxx 50 stable, IBEX 35 (Madrid) -0.8% Spot gold: $1989.89 USD Iron ore: $103.61 USD Bitcoin: $44,524.96 AUD

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Good morning sunshine
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business news team with you. I'll be keeping you up to date with the markets and business news all day. Tomorrow, the board of the Reserve Bank of Australia meets to decide the direction of monetary policy - essentially if interest rates will go up, pause (most likely) or go down (very unlikely). But there's plenty on before that. The ASX 200 futures market - where traders essentially bet on where the index will go today - is up 0.7% or 54 points, probably off the back of indicies in the US and UK lifting in last trade. Anyway, new month, big day, let's get started...

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live updates: ASX starts again after lifting last week, global stock markets move

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASX 200: up 0.6% to 7,357.30 All Ordinaries: up 0.6% to 7,549.20 Aussie dollar: lifted 0.2% to 66.22 US cents On Wall Street: Dow +0.8%, S & P 500 =).8%, NASDAQ 0.7% In Europe: FTSE 100 +0.5%, Stoxx 50 stable, IBEX 35 (Madrid) -0.8% Spot gold: down 0.4% to $1981.74 USD Iron ore: $103.61 USD Bitcoin: down almost 4% to $43,134.05 AUD
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot at 1:00pm AEST

Here's what the bank says the government is trying to do, at the same time: maintaining fiscal discipline to assist monetary policy in bringing inflation back to the 2%-3% target range providing some targeted relief to cost-of-living pressures putting in place new arrangements to reverse the projected blowout in spending on a number of large programs (ie. NDIS, Aged care) implementing the AUKUS defence policy priorities further developing climate change policies implementing some tax reform and moving the medium-term budget outlook onto a more sustainable footing And don't forget — win the next election so you can start working on the really hard stuff! That said, there's some good news for Treasurer Jim Chalmers. There was a budget last year — in October 2022 — to enact a lot of election promises. The 2022/23 budget deficit is expected to come in well below the estimate that was made then. Data to March shows the 2022/23 deficit running at $A11.2 billion "a substantial $A23.3 billion lower than expectations". If you roll it over 12 months like in this chart, the budget is back to a (very) small surplus — mainly thanks to the strong labour market and company profits.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal Budget in a week

children.content: Look, the most important day is always
But with the RBA meeting tomorrow and the Federal Budget next week, let's look ahead a bit.

The biggest bank in the nation, the Commonwealth Bank, has put out its preview of next Tuesday's budget and it spells out some assumptions that will help you frame the size of the challenge facing the nation.
Here's what the bank says the government is trying to do, at the same time:
maintaining fiscal discipline to assist monetary policy in bringing inflation back to the 2%-3% target range
providing some targeted relief to cost-of-living pressures
putting in place new arrangements to reverse the projected blowout in spending on a number of large programs (ie. NDIS, Aged care)
implementing the AUKUS defence policy priorities
implementing some tax reform and moving the medium-term budget outlook onto a more sustainable footing
And don't forget — win the next election so you can start working on the really hard stuff!
That said, there's some good news for Treasurer Jim Chalmers.
There was a budget last year — in October 2022 — to enact a lot of election promises. The 2022/23 budget deficit is expected to come in well below the estimate that was made then.

Data to March shows the 2022/23 deficit running at $A11.2 billion "a substantial $A23.3 billion lower than expectations". If you roll it over 12 months like in this chart, the budget is back to a (very) small surplus — mainly thanks to the strong labour market and company profits.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The index of Australia's 200 biggest listed companies has opened up in the first day of trading for the week. The ASX 200 is up 0.62% or 45.3 points to 7,354.30 points.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX 200 opens up 0.65%

children.content: The index of Australia's 200 biggest listed companies has opened up in the first day of trading for the week.
The ASX 200 is up 0.62% or 45.3 points to 7,354.30 points.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business news team with you. I'll be keeping you up to date with the markets and business news all day. Tomorrow, the board of the Reserve Bank of Australia meets to decide the direction of monetary policy - essentially if interest rates will go up, pause (most likely) or go down (very unlikely). But there's plenty on before that. The ASX 200 futures market - where traders essentially bet on where the index will go today - is up 0.7% or 54 points, probably off the back of indicies in the US and UK lifting in last trade. Anyway, new month, big day, let's get started...
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Good morning sunshine

children.content: It's Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business news team with you.
I'll be keeping you up to date with the markets and business news all day.

Tomorrow, the board of the Reserve Bank of Australia meets to decide the direction of monetary policy - essentially if interest rates will go up, pause (most likely) or go down (very unlikely). But there's plenty on before that.
The ASX 200 futures market - where traders essentially bet on where the index will go today - is up 0.7% or 54 points, probably off the back of indicies in the US and UK lifting in last trade.
Anyway, new month, big day, let's get started...

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There we have it — the local share market has managed to hold on to a gain and finish around a third of a per cent higher on Monday. That's despite losing steam through the afternoon— here's a chart of how the All Ordinaries tracked over the session: Meanwhile, the ASX 200 rose 0.35 per cent to 7,334.6 points, with big banks and energy stocks doing some of the heavy lifting. Mining stocks were a drag on the market, limiting the gains, with BHP and South 32 in the red, alongside gold and lithium miners. And Fortescue and Rio Tinto shares ended virtually unchanged. Here's how the different sectors fared on the benchmark index: And the biggest individual stock moves: Tomorrow is set to be an interesting day, with the Reserve Bank rates decision at 2:30pm AEST. Market pricing suggests no change to the cash rate for a second month in a row but some economists, including those at the Commonwealth Bank, are betting on a final 0.25% hike. My colleague Kate Ainsworth will be on deck early with all the overseas market action. Have a good afternoon!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Local market posts a positive start to the week

image.altText: A composite image of three women dressed for a red carpet

items.synopsis: It's the first Monday in May and it's one of the most photographed events in the world. Here's what to expect from this year's Met Gala and where you can watch it.

title.children: It's the event that costs $50,000 for a ticket. Here's when the Met Gala is and who's expected to show
